Award.AwardTitle: Latino Suburbia: Examining the Politics of Race and the New Immigration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Ana Aparicio (Northwestern University) will conduct qualitative research on the development of inter-group relations among three (Dominicans, Puerto Ricans, Salvadorans) Latino populations in suburban New York and on how they represent and perform cultural identities and political perspectives in public spaces. Recent census data reveal that Latino and immigrant populations comprise a significant and ever-growing segment of the population in non-urban locales in the United States. Through the use of ethnographic, interview, mapping, and archival methods, this study will document demographic, political, and social transformations occurring in a contemporary Latino suburb of New York with special attention to emergent forms of pan-Latino identity. Examination of these transformations will be understood and contextualized within three marked shifts in the contemporary U.S.: 1) the suburbanization of poverty in the the late 20th and early 21st centuries, 2) increasing levels of heterogeneity (with respect to class, race, citizenship status, and national origins) of Latinos and Latino immigrants in non-traditional receiving areas, and 3) increased legal attention to citizenship status in these landscapes.

This study will address a series of objectives: understand what places, policies, and processes affect the manner in which different groups relate to one another; develop analysis of how the political, economic, and social topographies of a locale affect the manner in which diverse Latino groups organize public events that signal identity and relationship; provide data and analysis of new immigrant destinations and how these populations are transforming suburbs and public spaces.

Research findings and outcomes will provide information about and contribute to theorizing on racial/ethnic formation, inter-group relations, immigrant politics, "Latinidad" (new identity movement), and urban-suburban transformations in the 21st century. The study will also offer a timely contribution to local and national debates about Latinos and immigrant policies in non-traditional receiving areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demographic, political, and economic shifts occurring in suburbs throughout the United States have been garnering much-needed attention. Some of this scholarly and mainstream attention has focused on the mortgage crisis, increasing poverty rates, and on undocumented immigrants in suburbia. The processes that were the focus of this research were: inter-group relations; the transformation of suburban public space; and the changing political, economic, and social landscapes of American suburbia. 

As Latinos and immigrants continue to move to suburbs - either after having been displaced from urban centers in the U.S. or moving there directly from Latin America or the Caribbean - their presence initiates changing social, economic, and political dynamics. Much of what happens depends on the local resident population and on the existent political climate. My research was carried out on Long Island, one of the most well-documented sites of suburban sprawl during the mid-20th century. The suburb on which I focused has been home to working-class white ethnics and Puerto Ricans since the mid-20th century. Since the 1980s, with the influx of large numbers of Central Americans, it has become a Latino majority suburb. My research focused on the ways in which these different groups of Latinos - all with different national-ethnic histories, income levels, racial locations, and immigrant/citizenship status - related to and/or worked with one another, as well as how, collectively, they have been changing the social, political, and economic terrains in this suburb of New York. 

This work reveals significant shifts happening in American suburbia and with new immigration patterns. Analysis developed from this study stands to make important contributions to policy, planning, and organizing in suburban sites, as well as to the scholarship and policy research on immigration, poverty, race, and suburbia.
